qas.question: What traditions do some Presbyterian churches only adopt as their doctrinal standard?
Many Presbyterian churches in America have adopted this doctrine as their standard, what is it?
The Presbyterian church in Canada has retains which Doctrine in its original form?
Which confession does the Presbyterian Church in America retain?

plausible_answers.text: historical period in which it was written

qas.question: What should be understood when reading the Westminster Standards?
South American Presbyterian denominations have adopted what type of standards?
The Bible is subordinate to which doctrine in Presbyterianism?
What are ruling elders required to subscribe?

context: Some Presbyterian traditions adopt only the <a0_0><b7_0>Westminster Confession of Faith<b7_0/><a0_0/> as the doctrinal standard to which teaching elders are required to subscribe, in contrast to the Larger and Shorter catechisms, which are approved for use in instruction. Many Presbyterian denominations, especially in North America, have adopted all of the <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>Westminster Standards<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> as their standard of doctrine which is subordinate to the Bible. These documents are Calvinistic in their doctrinal orientation. The Presbyterian Church in Canada retains the <a2_0><b3_0>Westminster Confession of Faith<b3_0/><a2_0/> in its original form, while admitting the <b4_0>historical period in which it was written<b4_0/> should be understood when it is read.
